FacilityName: EARTHGRAINS BAKING COMPANIES, INC. - FORT PAYNE

_prev_prog_3.Description: A PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM WHICH CONTAINS THE ELEMENTS REQUIRED BY 29 CFR 1910.119 IS IN PLACE AT THE FACILITY.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Earthgrains Baking Companies, Inc. (Earthgrains), a wholly owned subsidiary of The Earthgrains Company, owns and operates a commercial bakery facility in Fort Payne, Alabama.  It is the policy of The Earthgrains Company to comply with all applicable federal, state and local environmental and safety laws and regulations, and to conduct its business in an environmentally sound manner that avoids any unreasonable adverse impact on the environment or its neighboring community.

In keeping with this policy, The Earthgrains Company has developed and implemented a risk management program to ensure the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The risk management program includes procedures to (1) identify potentially hazardous chemicals at the facility, (2) for maintaining a safe working environment and, thereby, help prevent the release of hazardous chemicals, and (3) for minimizing the consequences of a release should one occur.


Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Earthgrains? Fort Payne facility makes various bread, bagel, and snack cake products.  The major processes at the Fort Payne facility include flour handling and storage, ingredient mixing, dough proofing, bread baking, product packaging and distribution.  Raw materials are delivered to this facility by trucks.

The only RMP regulated chemical handled by Earthgrains at the Fort Payne facility is anhydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is used at the facility in the refrigeration system for cooling the building, making ice, and freezing products.  The anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is a closed loop system.   Anhydrous ammonia is delivered to the facility by supplier tank trucks to initially charge the system and occasionally thereafter to top-off the system during hot weather conditions.  

Earthgrains has in place policies that limit the amount of ammonia at the facility.  In addition, this fa

cility complies with the ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 15 for ammonia refrigeration.  Ammonia is also subject to OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations; therefore this chemical is subject to the RMP Program Level 3 requirements.


Worst-Case and Alternate-Case Release Scenarios

The worst-case release scenario for toxic substances, by definition, is the maximum amount of that toxic substance that could be released over a 10-minute period from the storage vessel and ancillary piping.  The maximum amount of ammonia stored in the storage tank and ancillary piping, valves and other miscellaneous equipment is 17,500 pounds.   Based on US EPA?s RMP*Comp program, the specific distance to the toxic endpoint is calculated at 1.7 miles, which extends beyond the facility?s plant boundary.  Approximately 777 people live within 1.7 miles of the facility as determined using census data provided by the Landview III program.  Topographic maps and visual receptor surveys indicate that the area within 1.7 miles from the facility has other industrial properties, churches, public recreational areas and two schools.

The alternate-case release scenario for the ammonia system at Earthgrains Fort Payne facility has been defined as a truck ?pull-away? failure during system charging operations.   Assuming that the active mitigation devices work as designed, the most that would be released during this scenario is the contents of the filling hose (approximately 3? dia. x 25?).  The distance to the toxic endpoint for this scenario is estimated using a release duration of 1 minute.  Based on US EPA?s RMP*Comp Program, the conservative distance to the endpoint is calculated at 0.1 miles, which extends beyond the facility?s plant boundary.


General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Specific Prevention Steps

The Earthgrains? Fort Payne facility is subject to both EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention program and OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  Under both of these progra

ms, the facility has outlined specific procedures that it follows to prevent or minimize the release of anhydrous ammonia to the environment.  Specifically, the facility has performed a process hazard analysis (PHA) of the ammonia system and will repeat this process at least every 5 years.  The purpose of the PHA is to provide a systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards associated with the ammonia system.  In addition, the facility performs regular training of its employees to ensure that the procedures developed for the safe use and handling of ammonia is adhered to all the time.  Finally, the facility has a regular inspection and maintenance program to ensure that the ammonia system is operating according to specific safety standards.  Earthgrains believes that safe operating practices and accident prevention are the way to do business everyday.


Five Year Accident History

Earthgrains? Fort Payne facility has had one accidental release of ammonia in the last 5 years.  The release occurred on November 2, 1999 when the casing on a solenoid valve failed causing the release of anhydrous ammonia into the engine room of the bakery.  Due to the effective emergency response procedures in place at Earthgrains? Fort Payne facility, the amount of ammonia released to the atmosphere was significantly minimized. 


Emergency Response Program

Earthgrains? Fort Payne facility has developed a written emergency response program for the ammonia system and has provided training to its employees on its implementation.  In the event of an emergency involving the ammonia system, it is Earthgrains policy to immediately notify the Fort Payne Fire Department and request that they respond to the situation.  Earthgrains has discussed this policy with the Fort Payne Fire Department and has a written letter of agreement that outlines how emergency responses will be handled.  Earthgrains has confirmed with the fire department that they have the necess

ary equipment and training to respond effectively to an accidental release of ammonia from this facility.  Members of the local fire department have also performed inspections of the ammonia system at the facility. 


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Earthgrains? Fort Payne facility recently made changes to the ammonia system as a result of the investigation following the ammonia release that occurred on November 2, 1999.  No other planned changes to the ammonia system are planned at this time.  Since the ammonia system is regulated under OSHA?s PSM program however, it will be subjected to regular process hazard analyses reviews for the purpose of identifying and implementing potential improvements.
